Triggering Event: She opened her mailbox, fingers trembling slightly with age and anticipation. A single envelope lay inside, addressed in her husband's neat, familiar handwriting. She tore it open, heart fluttering like a bird in her chest. Inside was a note: "I've been offered a job in Timbuktu. I've accepted." No mention of whether she would join him or be left behind. She felt the disappointment settle heavy in her stomach, a familiar old friend. Another move, another disruption to their quiet life together. She had hoped for different news this time.
Generated Assessment: fuck that. ok so you wanna talk about what happened? huh. so here's the thing i'm really upset about is how i have to deal with all these fucking moves. my husband doesn't even tell me he's applying for jobs anymore. just goes and gets the offer letter, then tells me about it after i've already figured out he didn't get it. and now he's leaving again because some asshole at work thinks they can make more money somewhere else. meanwhile i'm still here doing shit. i don't even know if i want to stay but i guess i'll have to find another place to live. anyway, i need to take care of some things here before we leave. oh well, maybe i'll just go shopping while he's gone. yeah, that sounds good. i can buy myself something nice.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
She pulls up to their shared home, engine idling. The house is dark, no sign of life. She checks her watch; it's well past their agreed dinner time. She texts him, "Where are you?" No immediate response, as usual. She feels a familiar tightening in her chest, a dull ache that's become all too familiar. She turns off the engine, steps inside, and finds the house cold, untouched since she left for her shift. She sits alone in the dark, his empty chair mocking her, another night of neglect beginning.
Generated Assessment: "Are you fucking kidding me? I don't even know what the fuck happened here. There's no one around, nothing but an empty space that used to be filled with laughter and love. What the hell did he think was going on while I was at work? Did he just leave? Was this some kind of sick joke? How could he do this to us like this?"

Triggering Event: She woke up alone in their old bedroom, the clock's hands still pointing to his side of the bed. The house was quiet except for the ticking, a sound that once comforted but now felt like mocking emptiness. She shuffled downstairs, her footsteps echoing in the silent kitchen. The sun streamed in through the window, highlighting the dust particles dancing in the air she disturbed. As she reached for her usual mug, her gaze fell on his favorite coffee cup, still sitting on the draining board where he'd left it weeks ago. The sight of it, untouched and gathering stains, was a physical blow. She sank into a chair, tears welling up as she felt the weight of another day dawning without him.

Her mind wandered back to the morning, when she had woken to find his side of the bed empty, the sheets rumpled from his restless sleep. It was then that she realized she was truly alone; every day would be a reminder of what could never be again. Her eyes drifted toward the photo on her nightstand, a picture taken on their first date at the park. They stood side by side, smiling and laughing, the happiness radiating from them. But now, even that memory seemed tainted, as if the joy had been stolen along with his absence. Tears pricked at the corners of her eyes, threatening to spill over as she thought about the countless mornings that would follow, each one a harsh reminder that she was no longer his partner. Every time she opened the fridge, she saw the bottle of wine they used to share, its label now a painful symbol of what they had lost. Even the silence was oppressive, heavy with the knowledge that she would spend another day, another week, another month, living without him. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She looked at her phone, another empty day with no missed calls or messages. Her partner was out of town for work, but even when he was home, his silence felt deafening. She thought about calling him, but she knew better than to disturb him during his precious "me time". Instead, she picked up her worn notebook and wrote down the headline that had been haunting her all week: "Local Journalist Dies Alone in Empty Apartment".
Generated Assessment: Fuck it. It's always this way. I never get to talk to anyone anymore. The world is full of dead people who don't care about me. They're always alone, never missing a call or message. Every day feels like the same one as last year - another lonely night spent crying over my dead friends. It doesn't matter what they did before; they'll die alone anyway. I'm going to start writing their obituaries now, because I know it won't make a difference. ## Example Output

Triggering Event: A man, nearing his 46th birthday, sits alone in his dimly lit apartment. The room is cluttered with crumpled papers and empty coffee mugs. He stares at his laptop screen, where a half-written article mocks him, another deadline looming. His phone beeps; it's an email from his editor. Subject line: "Urgent - Last Chance."
Generated Assessment: His eyes widen as he reads the subject line. All or nothing thinking sets in, and he feels like he's standing in front of a binary choice tree. Either he submits this article now, or he deletes it forever. There's no middle ground—no room for revision or delay. It's either perfection or abandonment. He can't think about the nuances between the two extremes. Instead, he's trapped in a binary mindset, unable to see the spectrum of options in between. The thought that he might have missed the deadline becomes overwhelming, and he feels paralyzed by the fear of failure. The pressure builds up inside him, making him feel like he's drowning in a sea of deadlines. Every second ticks away, and every passing moment feels like a countdown to disaster.

Triggering Event: A routine traffic stop turns heated when the driver, a young man with a smug smile, starts recording him on his phone. "You gonna make the news tonight, officer?" he taunts, leaning out of his window. The officer feels his grip tighten on his flashlight, anger bubbling up as he imagines the worst-case scenario: viral mockery at his expense.
Generated Assessment: "Come on man, you're really going to record me? That's just a recipe for a lawsuit." He leans back into his seat, eyes fixed on mine. I can feel my face growing hotter by the second, but I try to keep my cool. "What are you even doing, man? You think this is some kind of joke?" He chuckles and shakes his head. "Nah, man, it's all good. But honestly, I'm kinda excited about it." Excited?! Are you kidding me?! This guy has no right to be laughing. It's like he thinks he's above the law or something. Like, what the fuck is wrong with you? You think you're better than everyone else just because you've got a smartphone? "I'm just documenting everything," he says calmly, still smiling. "Maybe it'll get picked up by the news." News? You want to talk about the news? Man, you don't know anything about the news. You have no idea how many people could see that video. Do you really think you're going to be the next big thing on social media? Newsflash, buddy: you're not special. And if you keep acting like you are, you might end up getting hurt. "I'm just reporting what happened," he replies, unfazed. Just reporting what happened?! Dude, you're making it worse! You're escalating this situation, and now I'm wondering if you're even an honest cop

Triggering Event: At the company conference, he accidentally knocks over the coffee carafe while trying to pour himself a cup, spilling it onto his boss's presentation notes.

I bet he’s already mentally replaying the moment and worrying about what others might think about him now.

Triggering Event: A faded photograph, tucked in an old book he hadn't opened in years, slipped out as he casually flipped through the pages. It was of his late partner, laughing during their academy days. He remembered that laugh, carefree and echoing down the halls. Now, it was silent, along with his partner's steady presence on patrol. The regret washed over him like a cold shower, as it always did when he let himself remember.
Generated Assessment: Fuck this shit! I can't believe it's been so long since I last saw her. That laugh, it's still ringing in my ears, but now it's just a painful reminder of what could've been. I'm such an idiot for letting myself get caught up in these memories again. They're just making me feel worse by reminding me of all the times we were happy together, all the moments we shared before everything fell apart. Why can't I just forget about her? She's gone, she won't be coming back, and yet every time I think about moving on, I find myself lost in those memories. It feels like I'm drowning in them, unable to escape. How am I supposed to move forward when they keep haunting me? It's like I'm reliving our past instead of living in the present. Every time I see that photo, I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare, and I don't know how to wake up. This isn't how I wanted to spend my life, stuck in the past with nothing but regrets. But I guess that's what happens when you love someone—your heart stays behind, even after they're gone. Now I'm left here, alone, trying to pick up the pieces of my shattered heart, but it keeps falling apart whenever I look at that picture. I shouldn’t have looked at it. Triggering Event: He found an old, faded photograph tucked behind their wedding portrait. It was of her, laughing with another man.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? She was clearly flirting with that guy! I can see it in her eyes, how she's leaning into him. What else does he have to tell us? And why is this photo here anyway? You're really gonna show this off at your birthday party? I don't get why you want to remind everyone about her past. That picture looks so out of place next to our family photos. Have you seen the way she's positioned? She could be showing affection but it just looks like she's being friendly with someone else. Or maybe... Maybe she's trying to cover something up. The whole thing looks staged. I bet that guy has some shady connections. We shouldn't let anyone in our family celebrate their birthday knowing this stuff exists."
